Comment: the Ruy Lopez, probably one of the most analyzed opening systems in the world; played for the first time in my life...

the usual and strongest reply...  other options are the Cordel variation Bc5, c3, Nf6, d4 - reminiscent to the Italian Party - or the Bird defense Nd4, Nxd4, exd4, 0-0, c6, Bc4, Nf6, bringing us back to Italian lines again...
again the usual and strongest reply... another option is the Exchange variation Bxc6, dxc6, 0-0; brought to life again by Fischer at Havana 1966...

business as usual; White could also consider the ancient Steinitz favorite d3, which is a bit slow, but very playable for White; which again Fischer showed us on several occasions in tournament play... we will try this on a next occasion...

business as usual; White could also consider the ancient Steinitz favorite d3, which is a bit slow, but very playable for White; which again Fischer showed us on several occasions in tournament play... we will try this on a next occasion...

from here, Black has usually three choices; a) open defense: Nxe4, d4, b5, Bb3, d5, dxe5, Be6, c3; b) closed defense: Be7, Re1, b5, Bb3, d6, c3, 0-0; c) d6 defense: d6, Re1, b5, Bb3, Na5, d4, Nxb3... in this game, Black clearly hasn't decided yet...
Black clearly ran out of theory already, and is trying to make a futile point about e4; giving White time for additional development...
Black clearly ran out of theory already, and is trying to make a futile point about e4; giving White time for additional development...
introducing Nd5 into the mixture... another strong option here is the usually played (Fischer) a4, to release Bb3, but Nc3 makes this all the more stronger after Bb7; plus: e4 is suddenly covered...
Black closes his defenses; since we are preparing Nd5, we pass on a direct d4, exd4, Nxd4, Nxd4, Qxd4, c5!, Qe3, with too much complications; this old Steinitz move covers e4 after Nd5...
Black closes his defenses; since we are preparing Nd5, we pass on a direct d4, exd4, Nxd4, Nxd4, Qxd4, c5!, Qe3, with too much complications; this old Steinitz move covers e4 after Nd5...
a clever addition, if I may say so myself; keeping an eye on b4 and a5 after Nd5...
a clever addition, if I may say so myself; keeping an eye on b4 and a5 after Nd5...
Black wants to complete his development; best is first Nd4, Nxd4 (Nxe5, b4!, Ne2, Nxb3, axb3, d5! (ruining my plans), exd5, Qxd5), exd4, to simplify before Nd5 hits...
now or never; this will clear a path either for c4 or d4, after an additional c3...
not the best: Black should be preparing Nd8 (Na5 is impossible) to trade Bd5, and prepare c6 or c5; Qd7 (solves it rightaway) or Qc8 (supports c6/c5) were options...
not the best: Black should be preparing Nd8 (Na5 is impossible) to trade Bd5, and prepare c6 or c5; Qd7 (solves it rightaway) or Qc8 (supports c6/c5) were options...
not the best: Black should be preparing Nd8 (Na5 is impossible) to trade Bd5, and prepare c6 or c5; Qd7 (solves it rightaway) or Qc8 (supports c6/c5) were options...

we need not protect a5 anymore, since Bb3 has been replaced, and cover the all important c5; after Na5, a4!, Bxd5, exd5, b4, Nd2, c6, Qf3, followed by c3 or c4, White has the better of the play... this is preventing Nd4, and preparing d4...
not better, than the above variation for Black; this might well be the losing move already...
still theory; enforcing d4, and preventing Nb4...
underestimating the situation; needed was a way to put the Knight elsewhere, like Qd7, followed by Nd8; this will soon go sour...

this move is what this variation is all about, and worth waiting for; now, Bd5 might even retreat to a2... needless to say, that also axb5 is a big problem; after c6, Ba2, threatening b4... Blacks' Queens' wing is about to fall apart, thanks to Rb8...
not better than above variation; Black needs to find a way to cover for Na5...
long overdue and a clear mistake at this point; last option was c5 (covers Na5), axb5, axb5, Nd2 (against e4, supporting c4), Ra8...
long overdue and a clear mistake at this point; last option was c5 (covers Na5), axb5, axb5, Nd2 (against e4, supporting c4), Ra8...
no other option left; (also) after Rxb5, c4, and after e4, Nd2, leaves Na5 lost... after Nb7, bxa6, Nc5, b4, e4, bxc5, exf3, Qxf3, Bxc3, Ra3, Bb4, c6!, Black can start worrying...
no other option left; (also) after Rxb5, c4, and after e4, Nd2, leaves Na5 lost... after Nb7, bxa6, Nc5, b4, e4, bxc5, exf3, Qxf3, Bxc3, Ra3, Bb4, c6!, Black can start worrying...
